results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel is of the filmmaker’s daughter Jean and her visitor, Toddy. Toddy is in military uniform when he rounds a corner of a house to chat happily to Jean, with their dog and pet birds. While on leave from the RAF, Toddy was billeted to the family home in Essendon during his time in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:01:00 Toddy enters the frame from a side path of to visit Jean at her home
00:00:12:00 Jean leans out the window to chat to Toddy
00:00:16:00 Toddy enthusiastically welcomes a dog into the scene
00:00:20:00 Jean presents two pet birds on her arm for the camera

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander (Alex) Nicoll (1898–1968) grew up in Princes Hill in Melbourne.

As a young man, and after working in various capacities, Alex met wealthy business owner Arthur Thomas who assisted him into business running an import agency at Tasmania House in Flinders Lane. Alex would enjoy a lifelong involvement with Melbourne’s ‘rag trade’ (clothing business) in Flinders Lane, including serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

In the 1930s Alex inherited an Agfa 16mm camera, projector and collapsible screen from Arthur Thomas who had been a keen photographer, and over the 1940s and 1950s would capture wonderful moments around Melbourne such as the celebrations for the 1956 Olympics and visits to the beaches of Port Phillip Bay.

After Alexander died, his son Mac continued the family filming enthusiasm in the 1960s and 1970s. Around 2005, the Nicoll family decided to donate most of their collection of films to ACMI.

This reel captures a military parade likely to be sometime in the 1940s down Alexandra Parade, Moonee Ponds and some garden views.

Selected highlight list:

00:00:00:05 a crowd lines the street (most likely Mt Alexander Road near Moonee Ponds Town Hall, the family lived in Essendon)
00:00:00:28 soldiers parade down the street before a crowd of onlookers
00:00:00:51 parade passes a dais on which people stand, one in a mayoral robe and chain of office
00:01:12:00 military trucks and equipment can be seen in the parade
00:01:38:00 soldiers relaxing on the lawn with members of the crowd after the parade

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:01:01:00 woman walking down a path from the lighthouse at Airey’s Inlet
00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group walking trip by members of the ‘Walkabouters’ club to the Grampians (Gariwerd) in Victoria. It features the making of a ‘pit oven’ style barbeque and showcases the walking to be had by visitors through the many ravines and paths but also the grandeur of the sweeping views from what can seem like perilous pinnacles and lookouts.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Dreaming Place’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 views of the Grampians range off in the distance
00:00:56:00 driving through a small township
00:02:51:00 creating a ‘pit oven’ by setting a fire in a deep hole in the ground
00:02:59:00 stones are thrown into the flames and then covered with pieces of terracotta tiles on which meat in aluminium foil is placed for cooking
00:03:38:00 the pit is covered with a piece of metal, hessian bags, stones and dirt
00:04:15:00 a woman climber is helped to the top of some rocks
00:06:10:00 cars driving along a dirt road in the bush
00:06:44:00 an example of the the beautiful rock of the Grampians
00:07:07:00 sign for ‘Forest Commision of Victoria’ ‘Camp of the Emu’s Foot’
00:07:15:00 Indigenous art on rock walls
00:09:48:00 a still river which runs under a wooden walk bridge among tall reeds
00:10:19:00 a fenced off shallow cavern possibly with Indigenous drawings on the rock
00:10:35:00 views of Indigenous drawings up close
00:11:07:00 driving through the bush
00:11:54:00 grey patchy granite rock of the Grampians
00:12:29:00 a lone walker stands on top of a high peak
00:15:25:00 walking through the bush
00:17:00:00 groups of kangaroos and emus
00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures the scenery around the You Yangs and other nature spots in Victoria. Wallace includes lots of close-ups of wildflowers along the way as well as old farm machinery, some lovely old buildings, monuments, rocky outcrops, scrub, trees and sky.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:35:00 walkers in the scrub
00:03:22:00 a koala peers at the camera
00:03:36:00 remains of a wooden sluice in a creek that may have been an old gold mining site
00:03:50:00 hearing instructions or a talk at a campsite with a fire
00:04:45:00 setting off on a walk through farm lands and gates
00:05:05:00 sheep run across a paddock and a swirling, foaming river spilling across rocks with spectacular waterfalls
00:06:52:00 collecting driftwood by the dramatic river
00:07:18:00 scenes showing the treacherous route for walking the banks of the swollen, fast flowing river
00:09:54:00 jumping from rock to rock over a creek
00:10:18:00 using logs to cross a creek
00:10:27:00 hikers walk up a long grassy hill with some sheep running by, toward a gravel quarry or storage area
00:11:03:00 looking for rock specimens or stones in the gravel
00:11:13:00 some hikers stop for a chat before scrambling over a rocky part of the hills
00:12:15:00 flowers, mushrooms and toadstools
00:13:08:00 a long lizard close-up followed by a centipede
00:14:40:00 a trickling creek before scenes of rushing waters in a small creek
00:15:50:00 country roads
00:16:29:00 filming a photographer taking pictures of wildflowers followed by close-ups of flowers
00:18:16:00 several wild orchids
00:19:15:00 a campfire at night
00:19:44:00 stone monument with a plaque that reads ‘Erected 1951. In memory of the pioneers of Steiglitz and the discovery of gold 1851 - 1853’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace films the city of Shanghai in China, and its people. Crowded streets, heavy traffic (with many bicycles), houses, shops and other buildings, gardens, the city’s canals and port are features. There are scenes of people at work, and children in organised cultural activities, and a sequence of high-vantage-point views of the city dissolve into one another. The Jade Buddha Temple with its many statues is also featured.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Shanghai’, ‘Filmed by W.H.C’
00:01:26:99 carpet weaving
00:02:34:00 jade ‘Buddha Temple’ and its Buddha statues
00:04:57:00 various views of the city from high vantage points, in a sequence of dissolves.
00:05:56:00 young children at school or kindergarten
00:11:50:00 port and ships
00:13:41:00 shadow puppet play
00:14:04:00 young children in various music, calligraphy, arts and electronics activities in a sequence of dissolves. Some children wear the red scarf of the ‘Young Pioneers of China’ youth organisation.
00:15:45:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

After his signature opening title, ‘Round About Alice’, Wallace goes to the desert landscape around Alice Springs, in the Northern Territory, including close-ups of wildflowers and distance shots of ‘Mount Conner’. We see Alice Springs streets and landmarks, and the annual (since 1970) ‘Alice Springs Lions Club Camel Cup’ race. Features the historic Alice Springs Telegraph Station (1872), once also the site of ‘The Bungalow’ school, (1932-1942) for children then identified by government as ‘part aboriginal’. Wallace then films in the dramatic landscape of the ‘McDonnell Ranges’.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Round About Alice’, ‘A W.H.C film’.
00:01:10:00 classic Australian style windmill spinning in wind
00:01:14:00 Mount Conner in distance
00:03:26:00 Street scenes Alice Springs
00:03:47:00 John Flynn Memorial Church, Alice Springs, exterior and interior.
00:04:31:00 extended sequence of camel racing, including scenes of watching crowd, a Scottish pipe band, and particpants in fancy dress
00:07:21:00 night sequence with illumintaed ‘Lions Cup’ sign with outline of a camel in lihghts; fireworks
00:08:02:00 Anzac Hill War Memorial (dedicated 1934) at Alice Springs, followed by aerial views of the town
00:08:32:00 Alice Springs Telegraph Station buildings and surrounds
00:09:15:00 Gravestones in the Alice Springs Telegraph Station Cemetery
00:09:58:00 John Flynn gravesite memorial
00:10:19:00 Roadsign for Simpsons Gap followed by scenes of and in McDonnell Ranges, including camping activities.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Papua New Guinea May - June 1961; No.1’, shows landscapes, seascapes, vegetation, people, villages, boats, roads, cars and other infrastructure of Papua New Guinea. It includes aerial footage of sea, forest, and mountains, and scenes of the (former) Royal Australian Navy base HMAS Tarangau at Manus Island.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 activities at a small airport
00:00:43:00 ‘Trans Australian Airlines’ (TAA) seaplane
00:02:12:00 luggage being manually loaded onto Ansett Australia plane by local staff.
00:02:36:00 passengers file past local staff wearing distinctive ‘Anset AAA’ waist-to-calf tunics
00:03:21:00 brief glimpses of a rugby match
00:07:47:00 outdoor classroom with young students at work
00:10:27:00 group of men constructing (or repairing) a traditional village building
00:14:04:00 woman preparing coconut with a large knife
00:16:53:00 large ship (probably one of the Royal Australian Navy) in port
00:17:06:00 small monument bearing sign ‘Tarangau’ (Royal Australlian Navy base HMAS Tarangau, commissioned 1950)
00:17:26:00 sailors in white uniform lined-up on deck
00:17:37:00 ship moves off from port
00:20:52:00 a food market with many people
00:27:39:00 distinctive three-sailed boat
